PULGA  In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.
Six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou
continuation: - to - Palo Verde transmission line that running through the Sierra Nevada highlands is already in shambles .  This is a failure of the scheme ,  PG & E  s chief executive , Bill Johnson , told a state Senate commission last week .Its not a failure of the technology.Its not a failure of the equipment.It  s not a failure of the people who work on it . It  s a failure of the system .  PG & E  s problem is that the company  s distribution networks are too old and too vulnerable to the forces of nature .The corporation  s communication connections are so old and so vulnerable to the forces of nature that the company has had to spend billions of money just to keep them run . That  s why PG & E  s communication connections have been so critical to the Camp Fire  s devastation .The blaze , which began on Nov . 8 , scorched an area the size of Los Angeles , killed 85 people and destroyed more than 18 , 000 homes . PG & E  s distribution networks are so old and so vulnerable to the forces of nature
translation:
CAMP In December 2012, a severe winter storm toppled five steel poles supporting the same PG&E power lines minutes before the Camp Fire broke out.
Six years later, his 115,000-volt Caribou-Palo Verde transmission line through the Sierra Nevada highlands lies in ruins. PG&E CEO Bill Johnson told a state Senate committee last week that this was a failure of the entire plan. This is not a technology failure. This is not a hardware failure. This is not a human failure. Who is working on this? This is a system failure. PG&E's problem is that its distribution network is too old and too vulnerable to the forces of nature. The company had to spend billions of dollars because its communication links are so old and so vulnerable to the forces of nature. Just to keep them working. That's why PG&E's utility connections played such a critical role in the devastation caused by the Camp Fire. On September 8th, an area the size of Los Angeles burned, killing 85 people and destroying more than 18,000 homes. PG&E's distribution network is very old and vulnerable to the forces of nature.

input:
Polands ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate supreme court judges it forcibly retired, acting on an injunction issued by Europes highest court.
On Wednesday the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted the relevant legislation on
continuation: the issue to parliament . The European Court of Human Rights ( ECHR ) in Strasbourg had ruling in March that the PiS regime had broken the law by temporarily removing judges from their posts .The ECHR said the courts had been  illegally removed  and had not been given an opportunity to defend themselves . Poland  s supreme court had ordered the reinstatement of the courts , but the authorities said it would go ahead with the move anyway .The ECHR said the Polish government had failed to justify its ruling to remove the courts . The government  s move to reinstate the courts was the latest in a string of moves by the PiS regime that has raised worries in the West about the erosion of judicial sovereignty in Poland .The PiS cabinet , which arrived to power in 2015 , has also introduced a law on judicial change that it said is required to counter corruption . But critics say the law , which would eliminate some legal independence , is part of a broader move by PiS to tighten its grip on the judiciary .The European Commission , the EU  s executive arm , has advised Poland that it could face legal action over the legal improvements .
translation:
Poland's ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate a Supreme Court judge who was forcibly removed from office following an injunction from the European Supreme Court.
On Wednesday, the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted a bill to parliament on the issue. The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in Strasbourg ruled in March that the PiS government had broken the law by suspending judges. The ECHR said the judge was illegally removed from office and was not given an opportunity to defend himself. . Poland's Supreme Court has ordered courts to reopen, but authorities have said they will continue to reopen anyway. The ECHR said the Polish government could not justify its decision to close the court. The government's decision to restore the court is the latest in a series of moves by the PiS government that have raised concerns in the West about the erosion of judicial sovereignty in Poland. The PiS government formed in 2015 also introduced legislation to change the judicial system to fight corruption. But critics say the law strips some of its legal independence and is part of a broader move by PiS to tighten its control over the judiciary. The European Commission, the EU's executive body, has notified Poland that it may face legal action over legal reforms.

translation:
Hamid Ismailov's Uzbek novels, winner of the EBRD Literary Prize, pay particular attention to Central Asian literature.
On December 31, 1937, Abdullah Kodirov, Uzbekistan's most popular writer of the 20th century, was hanged by Soviet authorities. His novel The Death of Abdullah Kadyrov, published in 1940, remains the country's most famous literary work. It is also one of the most controversial in the country. The EBRD Literary Prize, awarded annually by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), recognizes the best books produced in Central Asia. The contest is open to both novels and non-fiction. The EBRD Literary Award goes to Hamid Ismailov's novel A Child's Story, which was translated into English in 2014 and won the EBRD Literary Award in 2015. This novel depicts the story of a girl, her father, and her parents. They live in a village in southern Uzbekistan. The girl's father, a teacher, is in love with her mother, a housewife. However, he is not allowed to marry her. The girl's father is determined to marry her off, and as a result of her efforts he ends up in a hilly village where he tries to convince the villagers to give her the girl.

A GP clinic in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away.
The changes at the Links Medical Centre come into force on Wednesday, May 1.
A statement
continuation: from the centre said : " As part of our ongoing attempts to reduce the number of people visiting the clinic in the future , we are introducing a telephone assessment process on a three - day a week basis . " This will provide us to easier manage the present waiting hours for patients with non - urgent appointments ." We would like to thank our patients for their patience and understanding as we make these changes . " This is a temporary measure which will be analyzed at the end of the three - day assessment phase ." We apologise for any inconvenience this might cause . " We would like to reassure our patients that we will continue to provide a complete range of health services at the Links Medical Centre . "

continuation: security , and machine learning to cybersecurity . Department of Homeland Security . We are enthusiastic about the possibilities of combining Cylance  s deep expertise in artificial intelligence and machine understanding with BlackBerry  s enterprise - grade security platform .

translation:
Leslie and John Brown with their daughter Louise, the world's first test-tube baby.
It is ironic that the parents of Louise Brown, the world's first test-tube baby, are currently ineligible for the Nobel Peace Prize because of their political activism. John and Leslie Brown, who gave birth to Louise in 1982, have been nominated for the award. They are one of two people competing for the prize, along with Malala Yousafzai, a teenage Pakistani activist who was shot in the head by the Taliban for advocating for a girls' school. The award will be announced in Oslo on October 12th. The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded to individuals and organizations who recognize outstanding achievements in promoting peace and reconciliation around the world. It was established in 1909 and has since been awarded to more than 1,000 people. Mr Brown, who died in 2012, was a member of the Labour Party. Mr Brown was a member of the Green Party. The couple met while students at the University of Glasgow. Mr Brown was a tutor and Mrs Brown was a pupil. They married in 1970 and had two children, Louise and John Brown Jr. Mr Brown was the Labour MP for Glasgow and Mr Brown was a member of the Scottish Green Party. Mr Brown served as the MP for Glasgow South West from 1997 to 2010. Ms Brown served as the MP for Glasgow South East from 1997 to 2010.

The Seattle area has a new biotechnology company -- and this one is going to try attacking cancer by examining antibodies instead of tumors.
Johnny Stine, founder and chief scientist of the new Spaltudaq Corp., said the approach, if it
continuation: works , might have a huge impact on cancer treatment . " We ' re going to see at cancer cells and find if we can find a way to broke them down so they can ' t get into the bodies , " Stine said ." We ' re going to look at the immune system and find if we can take rid of the cancer cells so they can ' t do anything . " Stine , a cancer researcher at the University of Washington School of Medicine , said the company is moving quickly to develop the technology , which is known as antibody - drug conjugates ." We ' re not going to wait for the FDA to approve it , " Stine said . " We ' re going to going ahead and do it . "Stine said the company plans to file for FDA authorization by the end of the year . The company is working with the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance , which is offering a $ 1 million grant to assist with the development of the technology .Stine said the new technology could have a huge impact on cancer treatment . " It ' s going to be a game - changer , " Stine said ." It ' s going to be the most important stuff in physicians in the next 20 years . "
translation:
A new biotech company in the Seattle area is trying to beat cancer by researching antibodies, not tumors.
Johnny Stein, founder and chief scientific officer of the new company Spartudac, said this approach, if successful, could have a major impact on cancer treatment. "We're going to look at cancer cells and see if we can find a way to destroy them so they can't get into the body," Stein said. "We're going to study the immune system and see if we can eliminate cancer cells so they can't do anything," said Stein, a cancer researcher at the University of Washington School of Medicine. Developing technology known as antibody-antibody conjugate drugs. "We are not going to wait until the FDA approves this decision," Stein said. "We're going to go ahead and do it." Stein said the company plans to apply for FDA approval by the end of the year. The company is partnering with the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, which is providing a $1 million grant to support the development of the technology. Stein said this new technology could have a major impact on cancer treatment. "This is going to be a game-changer. This is going to be the most important thing for doctors in the next 20 years," Stein said.

Eden Hazard was facing an extended ban for kicking out at a ball boy after the Football Association charged him over his sending-off in Chelsea's Capital One Cup exit at Swansea.
Belgian playmaker Hazard was already set to serve an automatic three
continuation: - game banned for his red card against the Swans , which will rule him out of Saturday ' s Premier League clash with Manchester United . The 28 - year - old was sent off in the first half of Chelsea ' s 2 - 0 defeat at the Liberty Stadium on Wednesday after appearing to kick out at a ball boy as the match descended into chaos .Eden Hazard was convicted by the Football Association over his sent off against Swansea The 28 - year - old was already set to serve an automatic three - game suspension for his green card against the Swans The player was convicted by the Football Association over his sent off in Wednesday ' s Capital One Cup defeat The FA confirmed Hazard had been charged and could face a further sanction for his actions . ' Eden Hazard has been charged by the FA with a breach of FA Rule E3 preceding his dismissal in Wednesday ' s Capital One Cup fixture against Swansea City , ' the governing body says in a statement .' It is accused that the Chelsea player committed an offence contrary to FA Rule E3 ( 1 ) ( a ) , ( b ) and ( c ) . ' It is further claimed that the Chelsea player committed an offence contrary to FA Rule E3 ( 1 ) ( d ) and ( e ) .
translation:
Eden Hazard was accused by the Football Association of being sent off during Chelsea's Capital One Cup defeat to Swansea and was facing an extended suspension for punching a boy serving the ball.
Belgian playmaker Hazard was already due to serve an automatic three-match ban for his red card against the Swans and was set to miss Saturday's Premier League game against Manchester United. The 28-year-old was sent off in the first half of Chelsea's 2-0 defeat at the Liberty Stadium on Wednesday after appearing to hit a ball boy during chaos. Eden Hazard has been censured by the football club. Due to his sending off against Swansea, the 28-year-old was already due to serve an automatic three-match suspension with a green card against Swansea. The Football Association found the player guilty after being sent off during Wednesday's Capital One Cup match. The defeated FA confirmed that Hazard had been charged and that he could face further sanctions for his actions. "The FA has charged Eden Hazard with breaches of FA Regulation E3 leading up to his dismissal in Wednesday's Capital One Cup match against Swansea City," the governing body said in a statement. He is accused of committing an offense by a Chelsea player contrary to FA Regulation E3(1)(a), (b) and (c). It is further alleged that the Chelsea player committed an offense contrary to FA Regulation E3(1)(d) and (e).

input: The vast majority of the 45 Amazon.com customers who have reviewed Bloomberg Businessweek writer Brad Stones new book, The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon, gave it five stars. Lone among them, however, is a
continuation: woman who writes under the pseudonym  Annie .  She  s been a loyal Amazon user for more than a year , and she writes that Stone  s book is  the most comprehensive and insightful look at Amazon yet .  Annie , who asked not to be identified by her last name , says that Stone  s book  presents the real Jeff Bezos , and I believe it  s going to be a game - changer .  Amazon  s influence on retail is undeniable . The corporation  s progress over the previous decade has been staggering , and it  s the most valuable business in the world .Amazon  s share of the U . S . e - commerce market is growing faster than any other company , and it  s on track to become the world  s leading store by the end of this year . Stone  s book takes a deep dive into Amazon  s business and culture , and it  s a fascinating read .It  s a must - read for anyone who wants to comprehend how a corporation that  s developed so quickly and become so big can be so secretive .

However, the only woman among them writes under the pen name Annie. This book is a must-read for anyone who wants to understand how a company that has grown so quickly and become so huge can be so secretive.

WASHINGTON  Republican David Yancey won a drawing to break a tie in the disputed 94th District race in Newport News Thursday however his opponent is expected to challenge the decision, possibly seeking yet another recount.
Control of the House of Delegates is
continuation: at stake in Thursday  s election , with Democrats needing a net win of 23 seats to take control of the chamber . The Board  s decision was arbitrary and capricious , and the Board  s decision was not supported by substantial proof ,  the campaign said .Signer stated in a statement Thursday that he was  greatly unhappy  in the decision .  I will continue to campaign for the people of the 94th District and the honesty of our elections ,  he said .I will
translation:
Washington Republican David Yancey won the toss and broke a tie in the controversial 94th District election in Newport News on Thursday, but his opponent contested the decision and likely called for a recount. expected to be sought.
Control of the House of Delegates is at stake in Thursday's election, with Democrats needing a clear victory in 23 seats to take control of the House. Republicans need to secure 23 seats to maintain a majority. Yancey, a Newport News City Councilman, led his Democratic challenger, longtime Virginia Beach Mayor Mike Signer, by 5,844 votes out of about 1.5 million votes cast. Yancey, who has served as a state representative since 2014, was declared the winner by the Virginia State Board of Elections after a recount. Signer's campaign filed a lawsuit in federal court challenging the results. Mr. Signer's campaign said in a news release Thursday that Mr. Yancey's victory was irrevocable. The council's decision was arbitrary and capricious, and the council's decision was not supported by substantial evidence, the campaign said. Signer said in a statement Thursday that he was extremely unhappy with the decision. I will continue to campaign for the people of the 94th District and the integrity of our elections, he said.

input: WASHINGTON  The professions expected to show one of the biggest job growth rates in 2017 and the largest growth in sheer number of jobs will be trade skills, according to a year-end report from CareerBuilder and labor market data provider Emsi.
continuation: Trade skills are expected to be the fastest - increasing profession in 2017 , with an increase of almost 30 percent ,  the report says . The review , released Thursday , also discovered that workers in the professional and business services , construction , education and medical care industries are expected to expand the most . The growth in trade competence is a reflection of the fact that the U . S . economy is becoming more globalized ,  says Emsi Chief Economist and co - writer of the report , Jason Furman .  We predict to see the greatest rise in trade skills in the professional and business services industry ,  Furman stated .CareerBuilder  s study also discovered that workers in the leisure and hospitality trade will grow the least in 2017 .  Leisure and hospitality employment are expected to grow by just 2 percent in 2017 ,  the report says . This is the smallest growth rate of any industry .  The review also discovered that workers in the transportation and warehousing industry will grow the most in 2017 .  Transportation and warehousing jobs are expected to expand by more than 40 percent ,

Washington CareerBuilder and Emsi, a labor market data provider, report that some of the fastest-growing jobs are expected to occur in 2017, with skilled workers expected to see the largest increase in overall employment. It will be a skilled job.
 According to the report, sales jobs will be the fastest growing occupation in 2017, expected to grow by nearly 30%. The study, released Thursday, also showed workers in professional and business services, construction, education and health care are expected to see the biggest increases. The increase in trade capacity reflects the reality in the United States. C. The economy is becoming increasingly global, said Jason Furman, chief economist at Emsi and co-author of the report. "We expect the greatest skills growth will be in the professional and business services industries," Furman said. CareerBuilder's research also found that leisure and hospitality workers had the lowest growth rate in 2017. Employment in the leisure and hospitality sector is expected to grow by only 2% in 2017, according to the report. This is the lowest growth rate of all industries. According to the affidavit , Richterova and Gonzalez were at the home in Brush Creek to pick up the owner  s son from school .Gonzalez and Richterova gotten into an disagreement , and Richterova left the house . Gonzalez followed her and threatened to shoot her , according to the affidavit .Gonzalez  s girlfriend , who was also at the home , intervened and attempted to broke up the fight . translation:

Richtelova and Gonzalez were at the Brush Creek home to pick up the owner's son from school, according to the affidavit. Gonzalez and Richterova got into an argument and Richterova left the home. According to her affidavit, Gonzalez chased her and threatened to shoot her. Gonzalez's girlfriend, who was also in the home, intervened and tried to break up the fight. According to testimony, Gonzalez grabbed Richterova by the neck and slammed her head against a wall. Gonzalez and two others then beat Richterova, according to the affidavit. Gonzalez's friend tried to help Richtelova, but she was also hit, according to testimony. Gonzalez's girlfriend called 911.
